Concure, Mito and Aizu Shoami did some nice things, but not up to Mito
standards.

Gordon
  -----Original Message-----
  From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
  Sent: Tuesday, July 08, 2003 7:17 AM
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Mito vs Mito shoami


  Rich & all,
  Alan is definitely correct.  While not always to my personal taste, there
were a number of Mito lines producing very high quality fittings.  Several
of these Mito lineage founders were students of leading kinko artists.  No
doubt the Mito Tokugawa branch family (with 350,000 koku revenue) and their
retainers were responsible for supporting these many skilled workers.

  The standardized plates, designs taken from copy books, large scale
production and relatively poor quality are characteristics of the Mito
Shoami.  Aizu Shoami workers did a lot of the same.

  There are some rather poor quality, unsigned Mito tsuba as well.  It's
probably possible to find a group of better than average Mito Shoami work
that exceeds the quality of the bottom of Mito production.  These lesser
pieces are probably the source of the confusion between Mito and Mito
Shoami.  I have seen some fairly insipid mumei tsuba with kanteisho to Mito.

  It's true that better Mito workers did copy Nara, Hamano and others, but
their copy work is nothing like the Mito Shoami stuff after the Nara style.
If anything the workmanship of the Mito copies is a bit over the top
compared with the originals.  It's also usually signed by the maker.

  There was a book on published 5-10 years ago on Mito swords and tosogu.
Mine is out on loan and I don't remember the title or author's name.  Does
anyone have one handy?  In any event, that's a good book to look through to
get a feel for the better Mito work.

  Jim



    Rich,
    I think you are mistaken in your appraisal of Mito work, the Mito Shoami
    never achieved much prominence but the Mito Kinko are among the best
artists
    who ever made fittings, particularly in the late Edo/Meiji periods with
    artists like Hagiya Katsuhei and Unno Shomin. They were also very able
    copyists, I remember Mr Ono some years ago showed me a well known Somin
    kozuka of a horse (seen from the rear) in takazogan, I asked him how to
tell
    the real thing from a Mito copy, he said the only difference was that in
the
    copy the horse stood more proud, or was it the other way around?
    Alan
